Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Frontiers in Time Series Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Big data permeates business, engineering, and science -- the number of connected smart devices, even excluding phones, tablets, and PCs, is projected to grow from billions to tens of billions within five years. Vast data is generated from sensors, GPS, RFID, medical devices, and emergency and energy systems, to provide rich information about untold aspects of the modern world. Despite the ubiquity and significant interest in mining such data, there are few existing analytical tools that are suitable. The investigator focuses on the development of new statistical methodology, extending application of these methods to new fields, and on increasing understanding of the theoretical challenges in data-driven model building and inference. The methods under development have the potential to strengthen research in numerous fields, including astronomy, economics, emergency medical services, neuroscience, and statistics itself.

Time series analysis is a rich and historic field, but it remains centered on univariate and low dimensional multivariate analysis. In recent years, big data has begun to permeate business, engineering, and science, but despite the ubiquity and significant interest in mining such data, there are few existing analytical tools suitable for data with a time structured format. The investigator studies the development of new high dimensional and functional time series (HDTS) tools to help researchers and practitioners meet increasingly ambitious inferential and modeling aims. Specifically, the investigator studies: (i) new methods for simultaneous modeling, inference, and forecasting of dynamic functional data; (ii) new structured regularization methods for modeling high dimensional time ordered data; (iii) new adaptive, yet methods of stability analysis for big data monitoring systems; and (iv) linking these new methods with emergent lines of inquiry and providing an infrastructure for answering critical research questions in a wide range of fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project made four key innovations: (i) new methods for simultaneous modeling, inference, and forecasting of dynamic functional data; (ii) new structured regularization methods for estimation of high dimensional time ordered data; (iii) new adaptive, yet stable methods of stability analysis for big data monitoring systems; and (iv) linking these new methods with emergent lines of inquiry and providing an infrastructure for answering critical research questions in a wide range of fields.

Specific accomplishments include: (1) Bayesian Framework for Multivariate Functional Dynamic Linear Models and Dynamic Shrinkage Processes; (2) Structured and Hierarchical Regularization Methods for Time Series Analysis; (3) Robust and Computationally Efficient Multiple Change Point Analysis Methods.

This new statistical methodology for modeling and inference of high dimensional and functional times series has shown potential to strengthen research in numerous fields, including astronomy, economics, emergency medical services, neuroscience and statistics itself. Within the scope of the proposed project, I have applied these new methods specially to economic and biomedical lines of inquiry. This includes financial yield curve modeling, neuroscience, and now COVID modeling.

Many high impact publications, conference presentations, and freely available software packages have resulted from this project. Fifteen PhD student were under my supervision over the course of this project, with the first nine now graduated. Two postdocs were also mentored, with one continuing and one now an Assistant Professor. One master's and one undergraduate student also completed their thesis under my supervision. Several Forecasting workshops were organized and a new course on Spatiotemporal Data Science was also developed as part of this project.
